reference.text: sound-producing toys A63H5/00 ; musical instruments or parts thereof, see the relevant subclass, e.g. G10D

systems using the reflection or reradiation of acoustic waves G01S15/00 ; generating seismic energy G01V1/02 ; signalling or calling arrangements, alarm arrangements G08B ; piezo-electric electrostrictive or magnetostrictive elements in general H01L41/00 ; transmission systems using infrasonic, sonic, or ultrasonic waves H04B11/00 ; loudspeakers, microphones, gramophone pick-ups or like acoustic electromechanical transducers H04R

note.note-paragraph: This subclass covers arrangements for generating mechanical vibrations in fluids.
This subclass covers also the production of sounds which may not be audible to human beings but which are audible to animals.

In this subclass, the following terms are used with the meanings indicated:
- "acoustics" and "sound" cover the technical field dealing
with mechanical vibrations at all infrasonic -, sonic - and
ultrasonic frequencies. However, generation or transmission
of mechanical waves, in general, is covered by subclass B06B ,
subject to the exception specified in Note (1) above.

title-part.text: Devices in which sound is produced by striking a resonating body, e.g. bell, chimes, gong

reference.text: combinations with clocks or watches G04B , G04C ; carillons G10F1/10 ;

title-part.text: the resonating devices having the shape of a bell, plate, rod, or tube
the sounding member being a bell
the sounding member being a tube, plate or rod
Details or accessories of general applicability
Bells for towers or the like

CPC-specific-text.text: for an oscillating bell which is driven once per cycle
for an oscillating bell which is driven twice per cycle

reference.text: means or arrangements for avoiding or reducing out-of-balance forces due to motion F16F15/00

title-part.text: in which the sound-producing member is rotated manually or by a motor
in which the sound-producing member is driven by a fluid, e.g. by a compressed gas
Devices in which sound is produced by vibrating a diaphragm or analogous element, e.g. fog horn, vehicle hooter, buzzer

reference.text: loudspeakers or like acoustic electromechanical transducers H04R

CPC-specific-text.text: arrangement or adaptation for ships B63B45/08 ; mechanically driven vibrators B06B1/10

title-part.text: by compressed gases, e.g. compressed air
driven by water or other liquids

note.note-paragraph: This group does not cover the construction of, or circuits for, broadband-transducers such as loudspeakers or microphones, which are covered by subclass H04R .

title-part.text: with a plurality of active elements
with means for generating current by muscle power
Details, e.g. bulb, pump, piston, switch, casing
Methods or devices for transmitting, conducting or directing sound in general
Methods or devices for protecting against, or for damping, noise or other acoustic waves in general

CPC-specific-text.text: protective devices for the ears A61F11/06

reference.text: ; sound insulation for vehicles B60R13/08 ; sound insulation for aircraft B64C1/40 ; sound insulating materials, see the relevant places, e.g. C04B26/00 to C04B38/00 ; reduction of noise on permanent way E01B19/00 ; absorption of air-transmitted noise from road or railway traffic E01F8/00 ; noise insulation, absorption or reflection in buildings E04B1/74 ; room acoustics E04B1/99 ; sound insulation in floors E04F15/20 ; gas-flow silencers or exhaust apparatus for machines or engines in general, for internal-combustion engines F01N ; intake silencers for internal-combustion engines F02M35/00 ; suppression of undesired vibrations F16F7/00 to G10K15/00 ; preventing noise in valves F16K47/02 ; noise absorbers in pipes F16L55/02 ; arrangements for suppressing noise in direct-contact trickle coolers F28C1/10 ; silencers for weapons F41

title-part.text: Methods or devices for protecting against, or damping of, acoustic waves, e.g. sound

note.note-paragraph: This group does not cover protecting against, or damping of, acoustic waves adapted for particular applications, which are covered by the subclasses for these applications, provided that there is a specific provision for this aspect.

reference.text: G10K11/16B takes precedence; gas flow silencers or exhaust apparatus for machines or engines in general or for internal combustion engine F01N , noise absorbers in pipes or pipe systems F16L55/02 ; noise absorption in air conditioning and ventilation F24F13/00C ; silencing exhaust or propulsion jets in aircraft B64D33/06

title-part.text: Plural layers of different materials, e.g. sandwiches

note.note-paragraph: When classifying in this group, classification is also made in subclass B32B , in so far as any layered product is concerned.

title-part.text: using time-delay networks comprising electromechanical or electro-acoustic devices
Beamforming, e.g. time reversal, phase conjugation or similar
Underwater, e.g. transducers for generating acoustic waves underwater
Details of active noise control [ANC] covered by G10K11/178 but not provided for in any of its subgroups
Appliances, e.g. washing machines or dishwashers
Copiers or other image-forming apparatus, e.g. laser printer
Hi-fi, i.e. anything involving music, radios or loudspeakers
Boxes, i.e. active box covering a noise source
Combustion, e.g. burner noise control of jet engines
Communication systems, e.g. where useful sound is kept and noise is cancelled
Earphones, e.g. for telephones, ear protectors or headsets
Computers, i.e. ANC of the noise created by cooling fan, hard drive or the like
Feeders, i.e. of the vibrating kind
Impact noise, e.g. from typewriter or printer
Panels, e.g. active sound-absorption panels or noise barriers
Radiation control, e.g. control of sound radiated by vibrating structures
Rooms, e.g. ANC inside a room, office, concert hall or automobile cabin
Rotating machines, e.g. engines, turbines, motors
Periodic or quasi-periodic signals in general
Synchrophasors or other applications where multiple noise sources are driven with a particular phase relationship
Aircraft, e.g. spacecraft, airplane or helicopter
Vibration, e.g. instead of, or in addition to, acoustic noise
Anti-Vibration-Control, e.g. reducing vibrations in panels or beams
Analogue, i.e. using analogue computers or circuits
Adaptive noise equalizers [ANE], i.e. where part of the unwanted sound is retained
Control strategies, e.g. energy minimization or intensity measurements
Copy, i.e. whereby an estimated transfer function in one functional block is copied to another block
Correlators, e.g. convolvers or coherence calculators
Cross-terms between multiple in's and out's
Eigenvalues, e.g. used to identify most significant couplings between actuators and sensors
Estimation of noise, e.g. on error signals
Sources, e.g. identifying noisy processes or components
Determination of spectrum characteristics, e.g. FFT
Filtering, e.g. Kalman filters or special analogue or digital filters
Information contained in memory, e.g. stored signals or transfer functions
Models, e.g. of the acoustic system
Identification of the environment for applying appropriate model characteristics
Modes, e.g. vibrational or spatial modes
Monitoring various blocks in the flow chart
Nonlinear, e.g. clipping, numerical truncation, thresholding or variable input and output gain
Resetting of the filter parameters or changing the algorithm according to prevailing conditions
Phase shift, e.g. complex envelope processing
Multiple acoustic inputs, single acoustic output
Multiple acoustic inputs, multiple acoustic outputs
Prediction, e.g. of future values of noise
Pretraining, e.g. to identify transfer functions
Random noise used e.g. in model identification
Sampling, e.g. variable rate, synchronous, decimated or interpolated
Speeding up computation or convergence, or decreasing the computational load
Transfer function of the acoustic system
Variation of parameters to test for optimisation
Active mounts for vibrating structures with means to actively suppress the vibration, e.g. for vehicles
Actuator details, e.g. composition or microstructure
Fluid amplifiers, e.g. modulated gas flow speaker using electrovalves
Architectures, e.g. special constructional features or arrangements of features
Cancellation means disposed in the vicinity of the source
Collocated sensor and cancelling actuator, e.g. "virtual earth" designs
Filters other than the algorithm-related filters
Headrests, seats or the like, for personal ANC systems
Materials, e.g. special compositions or gases
Radio or other sources used in ANC for transfer function estimation
Means to avoid interference between desired signals, e.g. from a car stereo, and the ANC signal
Sensor details, e.g. for producing a reference or error signal
Plates or thin films, e.g PVDF
Ageing, e.g. of the control system
Echo cancellation, e.g. multipath-, ghost- or reverberation-cancellation
Reviews on ANC in general, e.g. literature
Hybrid, i.e. combining different technologies, e.g. passive and active
Improving tonal quality, e.g. mimicking sports cars
Narrow band, e.g. implementations for single frequency cancellation
